resources.string: It is well-known that the Arabs preserved most of the wisdom and knowledge of antiquity in their writings when Europe was plunged into the Dark Ages. The knowledge and scholarship were re-translated back into Latin during the Renaissance by monk scholars, and medicine was no exception. It is therefore not surprising to find that Ibn Sinas descriptions of the pulse have been described by the Greeks before, most notably by Galen who controlled medical thinking for centuries. Galens teaching on the pulse dominated clinical practice for about sixteen centuries. Some of his books on the pulse have been lost but eighteen books are known to be extant and are regarded as authentic
